titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the J. Walter Thompson Company. Radio and Television Department Records, 1932-1978 and undated RL.11008
titlestmt.author: Michelle Roell, Richard Collier

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-01-23 13:07:53 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: J. Walter Thompson Company. Radio/Television Department records

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: J. Walter Thompson Company. Radio and Television Department

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History

did.abstract: Founded in 1864, the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT) is one of the oldest and largest enduring advertising agencies in the United States. Collection spans 1932-1978 and includes correspondence, contracts, reports, surveys, radio and television program scripts and other materials that document the operations of the JWT Radio and Television Department. The bulk of the materials pertain to interactions with several labor unions representing the interests of actors, writers and others involved in radio and television broadcast production, including: American Federation of Musicians (AFM), American Federation of Radio Artists (AFRA, later the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists--AFTRA), Producer-Composers and Lyricists Guild of America (P-CLGA), Radio-TV Directors Guild (RTDG), the Screen Actors Guild (SAG, later merged with AFTRA to form SAG-AFTRA), and the Television Authority. Sponsor companies represented include Ballantine, Ford, Kodak, Kraft, Lever (Unilever), Quaker Oats and Schlitz. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sale, Advertising & Marketing History.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

eventgrp.event: American Federation of Radio Artists (AFRA) founded
Radio Directors Guild (RDG) changes name to Radio and Television Directors Guild (RTDG)
The AFRA and TvA merge to form the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA)
The RTDG merges with the Screen Directors Guild (SDG) to form the Directors Guild of America (DGA)
JWT establishes the Radio and Television Department
SAG and AFTRA conduct the first joint negotiation for prime time network contracts
SAG and AFTRA enter into merger "Phase I" talks, but action is halted by an anti-trust suit
SAG and AFTRA finally merge to form SAG-AFTRA

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection spans 1932-1978 and includes correspondence, contracts, reports, surveys, radio and television program scripts and other materials that document the operations of the JWT Radio and Television Department. The bulk of the materials pertain to interactions with several labor unions representing the interests of actors, writers and others involved in radio and television broadcast production, including: American Federation of Musicians (AFM), American Federation of Radio Artists (AFRA, later the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists--AFTRA), Producer-Composers and Lyricists Guild of America (P-CLGA), Radio-TV Directors Guild (RTDG), the Screen Actors Guild (SAG, later merged with AFTRA to form SAG-AFTRA), and the Television Authority. Sponsor companies represented include Ballantine, Ford, Kodak, Kraft, Lever (Unilever), Quaker Oats and Schlitz. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sale, Advertising & Marketing History.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: Commercial Talent Contractors, Inc.; General Television; Card Files; Scripts; Television Programs by Sponsor; and Unions.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The J. Walter Thompson Company. Radio and Television Department Records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1987

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], J. Walter Thompson Company. Radio and Television Department Records, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials may be found in the following collections of the J. Walter Thompson Company Archives held in the Hartman Center:
